bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, November 11, 1952

div1.p: Hench describes the memorial ceremony that the Cubans are planning at Camp Lazear. He regrets that illness will prevent the Trubys and others from attending the ceremony.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, November 11, 1952
div1.opener:
write
minn.
Trel
November 11, 1952 General Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
My dear General Truby:
div1.p:
Thank you for your letter of November 5. The Cubans have not left out Lazear
or Carroll. They each are having a special medallion made, a profile. Five
or six round medallions will honor the main workers and will occupy (I am
told) the center of the wall. On either and will be a bronze tablet naming
others and I think you were looking at the list of names for those bronze
tablets on the side. However they did leave out Doctor Pinto and Captain
Stark. I spent many, many hours this summer collecting for Pedro a complete
list of everybody connected with the affair. I recommended the inclusion of
Doctor Pinto and Captain Stark but apparently the committee decided to honor,
at least on the main tablets, essentially those who worked at Camp Lazear.
However they later added a small list of names of those who cooperated,
including the names of yourself and General Kean. I did not recommend
the inclusion of Miss Warner's name but I did suggest the inclusion of
Ames and Lambert. Having sent my long list and my suggestions (a copy
of which I am sure I sent you) I later sent two or three other letters
to Pedro but when he and his committee (who else is on it I do not know)
made their final decision I just didn't have any more pep in me to argue
at long distance. I had hoped that some of those to whom I wrote would
write to him and make their own suggestions. Perhaps they did. If so,
I received no carbons.

Thank you for your note about Dr. Mazzuri and John Peter Barstow. I will
write the Minneapolis Tribune.

I am so glad that you are home again. You have had a long, hard time and
although undoubtedly you were splendidly cared for in the Letterman Hospital,
“there is no place like home.” How I wish I could drop in on you for a nice
whole day's chat. I shall fly to Havana, spend two or three days there and
fly back. Thereafter I will certainly write you and send you some photo-
graphs of the affair. If I were a millionaire, I would charter a plane and
pick up some very dear friends of yellow fever fame, you and Mrs. Truby
especially, and fly them down to this affair, but alas it seems to be illness
more than finances that prevents most of those who should go from going.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
